instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.A2159: What is A2159? A2159 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3301, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01598..
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG? This is battery power that flows to the system AFTER it has gone through a current sense resistor, before it goes through a fuse to become PPBUS_G3H power rail. .
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.820-01814: What is 820-01814? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Hi,

My wife's 2019 MBP died a couple of weeks ago and I have been trying to figure out what is wrong with it. I took it to Apple who diagnosed a logic board failure and quoted me around Â£700 to replace even though it's just a few months outside AppleCare warranty... I have an electronics background and equipment (microscope, hot air, soldering iron, oscilloscope etc) but never tried to diagnose a modern MBP before. I have the board view and schematics already and have been climbing the learning curve steadily! [IMG]https://www.badcaps.net/forum/images/smilies/icon_smile.gif[/IMG]

Initial fault was no power with USB ammeter showing 5.19V @ around 12 to 35ma. I won't go into all the initial debug I did because ultimately I found <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> to be high resistance when it should have been a 0ohm link. I'm using a genuine 96w Apple charger and cable which works fine on other MacBook Pros. The logic board is fully extracted from the chassis with USB-C sockets attached.

So, going from the power sequence chart in the schematics I get:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.29V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_GPU</SIGNAL> = 12.29V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SSD0_SNS</SIGNAL> = 3.38V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> = 0.02V (this led to <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> being diagnosed as o/c)

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> is also 3.38V which feeds the upstream side of <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR>.

I linked out <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> with some wire wrap for now and that now causes the USB ammeter to power up and shut down continually and I can't get a reading. I measured <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with my oscilloscope and the voltage is ramping up from 3.7v to 12.6v over the space of 170ms and then sustaining 12.6v for 70ms before dropping rapidly to 3.7v again.

I tried removing the <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridge and injecting voltage to the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_PMU_VINRTC_R</SIGNAL> line which <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> feeds and it takes 3.65A at 3.3V. I only ran at this level for a second because the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> Power IC starts to warm up even at 2A current draw at 2.65V injected. When injecting power I didn't see any voltage on the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> outputs.

I checked the T2 power rails as per logi.wiki and got the following. Took resistance measurement plus diode mode in brackets (red lead on ground):

<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 15.9ohm (0.021)
<SIGNAL>PP0V82_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> = 34.5ohm (0.032)
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE = 212ohm (0.637)
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 7.8kohm (0.402)
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> = 57.3ohm (0.054)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = >20kohm (0.390)

General observations - no signs of liquid damage and no corrosion. <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> has a somewhat "mottled" appearance under the microscope but no signs of burns. The <SIGNAL>PPGFX_S0_GPU</SIGNAL> line is very low resistance around 1.6ohm but not sure if this is normal. 

So, my guess is that <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is faulty but I'd appreciate a second opinion. I have a Quick 861DQ hot air station and Hakko FX-888D solder station and have some experience at using hot air but would appreciate nozzle size, airflow and temperature guidance for removing <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>. I would also appreciate any help in finding a source of a new or used/reballed chip. It says it's a 338S00267-A0 (1939PHGU) but I don't know if these are generic or specific to each individual MBP model.

Looks like the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> chip might be the same. From a quick check of the respective schematics, the BOM details are the same and the pin assignments seem to be the same from what I've checked so far (mostly the LDO section). Even the neighbouring passive components have the same designations and values. I also checked <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) but it has a different <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> chip with part number 338S00466 which has different pin assignments, and from checking a BGA stencil from see-ic on eBay, this chip has a different stencil to the 338S00267. The stencils are both 18x18 (324) pins but the pitch on the 466 is very slightly larger than the 267 it seems.

I'd really appreciate any help you can offer.

Many thanks,
Craig.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

You should start checking diode mode to ground on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R9700</RESISTOR>.
If <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> got hot when injecting voltage there, it must be replaced.
Apart of it, remain 4 capacitors; they should be good, if none got hot.

If you find similar PMU from different MLB, give it a try.
Just be sure to have the same printout.
The PMU has many GPIOs, defined by its internal firmware.
But I can confirm that the one from 01041 board yes, it works on 01700 board.
The one from 00850 should also work.

CPU and GPU core power rails have very low resistance to ground as normal; don't bother with that.

I can't tell you more about hot air station.
Same setting may not work exact in same way on every model.
I recommend you to practice on scrap boards.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Hi, thanks for the welcome, and for the fast response.

Diode mode readings for <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> (I presume you meant that and not <RESISTOR>R9700</RESISTOR>) are 0.417 (red lead on ground) and 0.753 (black lead on ground). This is with my link wire still attached between <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> pin 1 and 2. Do you want me to do the same readings with the link removed?

This reading seems okay to me but I don't have a good board to compare against. I wondered if it was an output from the PMU that was shorted but I tried checking all the inductors to ground in diode mode and couldn't find any obvious shorts. When I said the PMU was getting hot, I didn't let it get "ouch!" hot but it was certainly warming up once more than 1.5A was flowing into it. 

You mention the PMU's internal firmware - is this coded on the PMU itself or does it come via an external ROM?

I have ordered a BGA reball kit with a clamp, a selection of solder balls and universal stencils which should be here tomorrow. I've also bought an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board from eBay as a potential donor. The board has already had NAND removed so was quite cheap and appears to still have the PMU installed so I'll give it a try. I can hopefully also salvage <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> from it to replace it properly and any other passives.

No worries about the hot air advice, I understand. I'll practice on the donor board before attempting the PMU swap.
Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Is true, my error about <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> (not <RESISTOR>R9700</RESISTOR>).

If no short on PMU input power rail, check diode mode to ground at its LDOs; page 76, (SYM 1 OF 4).
Use the capacitors connected there, as test points; don't forget <SIGNAL>VOUT_RTC</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Okay I checked all the pins in Sym 1 of 4 section as follows (all with red lead to ground):

V3P3/<SIGNAL>VOUT_RTC</SIGNAL> = 0.377
<SIGNAL>LDO0_IN</SIGNAL> = 0.253
<SIGNAL>LDO1_IN</SIGNAL> = 0.416
<SIGNAL>LDO2_IN</SIGNAL> = 0.392
<SIGNAL>VIN_RTC</SIGNAL> = 0.415
<SIGNAL>LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> = 0.367
LDO0 = 0.214
LDO1 = 0.468
LDO2 = 0.527
LDO3 = 0.595
<SIGNAL>LDO_RTC</SIGNAL> = 0.368
<SIGNAL>HIO_SW_EN</SIGNAL> = 0.473
<SIGNAL>HIO_SW</SIGNAL> = 0.222
VPUMP = 0.574
<SIGNAL>V3P3_SW1</SIGNAL> = 0.641
<SIGNAL>V3P3_SW2</SIGNAL> = 0.327

Do these look okay to you? Anything else I can check before swapping the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> IC?
Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message: Check if there appear some voltages (LDOs) when power it normally (not injecting).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Voltages at LDOs:
LDO0 = 0.000V
LDO1 = 0.000 - 0.003V
LDO2 = 0.000V
LDO3 = 0.000 - 0.001V
<SIGNAL>LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> = 0.000V
<SIGNAL>LDO_RTC</SIGNAL> = 0.000V mostly with a little 20mV ramp up and down each time the USB-C ammeter cycles
<SIGNAL>VOUT_RTC</SIGNAL> = 0.450V (starts lower at 200mV and each time the ammeter cycles it rises a bit farther. Also takes a long time after power down to bleed away so I guess there is a lot of capacitance on this line)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message: Then change <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Thanks, I'm expecting the donor board to arrive on Saturday so will hopefully have a go at replacing <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> over the weekend. I'll let you know how I get on.
Have a lovely weekend.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Hi again,

My donor board didn't arrive until yesterday so apologies for the delay.

Well, I replaced <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> with a new part from "see-ic" on eBay (China) and initially I hadn't used enough heat to fully melt the lead-free solder so I was getting 5.2V on the USB-C ammeter but 0.000A. I inspected the solder balls along one edge of <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and it was clearly not melted so I did a reflow at a higher temperature with more flux added.

It took a lot of heat and honestly I'm not 100% sure if I did it correctly without damaging the chip but after cooling I tested it again and I get the exact same symptoms I had before I replaced the chip. My ammeter is cycling and never gets to show a voltage or current, and my LDO outputs show no voltage except for LDO3 which briefly pulses up to 160mV or so on the multimeter each time the USB-C ammeter cycles. I still get 12.29V on PPBUS.

As I mentioned, I used the new PMU chip rather than the one from the donor board but I have extracted the one from the donor board and have manually reballed it with leaded solder balls and could try installing it. But before I do that, I wanted to update you and ask how likely it is to have the exact same symptoms after a PMU replacement? If I installed it badly or overheated the chip during installation, would it show the same symptoms as before?

Many thanks,
Craig.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message: Do you now get V3P3 and <SIGNAL>VIN_RTC</SIGNAL> at <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
V3P3 (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SOCPMU</SIGNAL>) is at ~ 220mV
<SIGNAL>VIN_RTC</SIGNAL> is mostly at 0V but with some pulsing on the multimeter to a 20-50mV as the USB-C ammeter cycles. I still have the temporary link wire in place to bypass the failed <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message: If you remove the <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bypass, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> are stable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Actually no, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is now cycling between around 3.7V and 11V+ even with the <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> link removed and <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> is pulsing between 0V and just over 1V with the other side of <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> (<SIGNAL>VIN_RTC</SIGNAL> of the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>) floating between 0.4V and 0.6V. 

So something seems to have changed somewhere and maybe I need to take a few steps back and verify <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and come forward from there. Strangely, I did check PPBUS and it was at 12.29V but that might have been before my second reflow of <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>. Will try to diagnose <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> this evening unless you have any other specific things to suggest.

Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Update: I still wasn't happy with the soldering of the PMU because the visible balls along the top edge were not looking like they had flowed. I think I was just not prepared for the amount of heat required by lead-free solder, especially on a power chip with presumably large ground planes etc. 

It definitely flowed this time but spat out some solder balls along the bottom edge which I cleaned up. The balls on the top edge now look like they have settled down and flowed and the chip is closer to the PCB surface. But I fear that repeated heating may have destroyed the chip. In particular, prolonged heating at temperatures just not quite hot enough to flow the lead-free solder. I didn't have this problem when I practiced on the donor board by installing the PMU from my good board because it was using leaded solder.

I'll do some diagnosis of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to see if I can find out why it is cycling but unless you have any better ideas, I think I should probably remove the PMU again and try installing the one I recovered from the donor board, with leaded solder this time. Failing that I might just have to admit defeat and send the board off to someone in the UK who does board level repairs. Recommendations welcome.

Have a nice weekend.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
You must get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, before going for <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
Remove F7000/1 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Yeah I understand the need for a stable <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. 

Before I removed the two fuses I noticed that the PPBUS_USBC_(XA/XB/TA/TB) power input was pulsing between 0 and 5.2V depending of which USBC port was being powered. 

With fuses F7000/F7001 removed <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> is stable at 12.27V (I guess it won't get boosted to 12.6 without the fuses installed?) and obviously <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is now 0V. The USBC ammeter shows 5.19V and 0.000A but it is also stable again.

If I do a diode mode reading on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> now it reads 0.383 so not a dead short. I'll start working my way downstream from the fuses and see where it leads. I won't inject any voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> unless you ask me to because I've read the warnings about this. But maybe we'll need to consider this at some stage.

I wouldn't be surprised if I find a rogue solder ball somewhere after my BGA reballing activities. Those things are a nightmare to keep control of once you open the bottle. I can see why many(most?) people use solder paste instead of balls!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Compare diode mode reading on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with all coils.
0.383 is not short to ground, but may have a shorted high-side MOSFET with a secondary coil; if any gives the same reading.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Since I took the readings earlier, the diode mode to ground (red on ground) for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> has changed slightly to 0.402. Maybe due to capacitors discharging while it was powered down for a couple of hours. 

Anyway, I used this 0.402 figure to search for a coil with similar diode mode value to ground (again red on ground) and found L7600. This coil works with <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> dual MOSFET to turn <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH5V</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> via current sensor) into <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>.

I did some diode mode checks on <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> Gate, Source and Drain in circuit and got these readings (first pin is red lead, second is black):
D to G = ramps up quite quickly to beyond 1.999
G to D = 1.354 stable
D to S = ramps up quite quickly to beyond 1.999
S to D = 0.476 stable
G to S = 1.356 stable
S to G = starts around 0.1xx and then slowly ramps up to 0.3xx before jumping to a solid 0.653 which is then stable

This doesn't jump out at me as being a faulty MOSFET but let me know if you disagree. I have one of these chips on my donor board so could swap it if you think that's worth a try.

Another coil, L7660 has a similar diode mode value of 0.374 but I checked the high and low side MOSFETs on that chip and there are no shorts either. 

Could it be <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> that is faulty? Again I have one on my donor board but the part number is TPS51980B on the 01700 board and TPS519080A on the donor board. Not sure if that is significant or not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Just check now diode mode, or ohm scale, between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and suspected coils.
If the reading is the difference between each one to ground, guess what...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Hi, I'm not sure if I'm doing what you are asking but here are the diode mode results with placement of red and black leads noted in the column headers. Nothing matches exactly and only the CPU and GPU supplies come close.

[ATTACH type="full"]61157[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Update: I think I've found the source of the short.

I found a short across <CAPACITOR>C7829</CAPACITOR> which is also connected to L7810 (Line PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE)

This line runs at 0.8V to 1.06V at 1A max so I set up 1V on my PSU and 1A current limit and injected voltage on this line using IPA alcohol to indicate the heat sink. 

What I found is that the PCB trace leading from <RESISTOR>R7811</RESISTOR> to the PMU was getting hot which is the feedback (PVDDCPUSRAMAWAKE_FB) line for Buck1. This line should not be taking any significant current and if you look at the PMU pinout it is surrounded by ground pins on 6 of 8 sides. So my guess is that there is a solder ball short to ground under the PMU chip due to bad soldering.

So, next step is to remove <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> again and either reball and replace that new chip or install the chip from the donor board. 

Question - the smallest solder balls I have are 0.25mm. Are these too large for the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> PMU or should they be okay? I think my mistake was not using enough heat initially for lead-free solder and then when I started to really ramp up the heat and got a bit desperate to see the chip float, I tapped it from above too hard and caused the solder balls to be ejected from the bottom edge. The shorted pin is 4 rows from the bottom edge so might have got a bridge at the same time.

Are we having fun yet! ðŸ˜‚

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message: I use solder paste for reballing...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Hi,
Happy to report that I have replaced <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (PMU) again and this time it looks as if it is working. I also replaced the two fuses and <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> and now my board is switching to 20V (20.54V actually) and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> goes to 12.6V. It draws up to 0.36A at 20.54V before dropping back to 0.000A after about 15 seconds. 

Should I try installing the board back into the top case now or do you think I still have a problem? I'm not sure whether it's normal to drop back to 0.00A when the board is disconnected from the battery etc.

Thanks,
Craig.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Do you note voltage on the big coils?
Are you using 96/140W charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Hi, yes I am using the 96w charger and associated genuine charging cable. 
While waiting to hear back from you I went ahead and installed the board temporarily in the top case and connected up the battery and BMU cable. Now when I plug it in, it goes to 20.5V and appears to start charging the battery. I get a steadily increasing current draw which levels off at 3.2A at 20.14V. The computer still doesn't boot up and I don't get a fan spin either. I tried the SMC reset process using left option, control, right shift and power but nothing changed.

Do you still want me to check voltages on all large coils?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message: Update: I managed to use the keyboard to get it into DFU mode and completed the T2 revive process. This ended with the DFU symbol on the host Mac changing to a lock symbol but still nothing on the display of the guest machine and no fan spin. I'll check for voltages as per the power sequence chart.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message: If no data needed, go for DFU restore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
I tried a second revive which also completed successfully but again with nothing shown on the display. I then did a DFU restore which also completed through to the lock symbol on the host computer but again no change. I just did that restore a second time with the same result. 

I noticed that during the DFU revive/restore, the 2V5 and 0V9 SSD voltages appear as well as the 1V8 and 1V1. But when not in DFU revive/restore, only 1v1 and 1v8 are present.

I did diode mode readings for the following lines:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0.326
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NANA_SSD1</SIGNAL> = 0.390
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NANA_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 0.380
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_NANA_SSD1</SIGNAL> = 0.369
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_NANA_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 0.350
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_NANA_SSD1</SIGNAL> = 0.405
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_NANA_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 0.363

I checked voltage on all main coils and only the following had any voltage:
L7030 (charger) = 0.60V (varying a bit)
L7600 = 5.13V
L7660 = 3.35V
L8410 (backlight) = 0.02V

USBC ammeter is sitting at 20.56V and 0.015 - 0.025A

If I press the power button the current drops top 0.000A within 2 seconds and the another ~8 seconds recovers back to 0.020A or thereabouts. This is repeatable. I wonder if this indicates a short in one of the power rails that only activates when the machine turns on.

Any thoughts on where I should focus next? It feels like it's very close to coming to life.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
If DFU was completed, SSD should be good.
At least the T2 partition is OK.

1V8/<SIGNAL>3V3_G3S</SIGNAL> come both on?
Check diode mode to ground at all outputs in page 79.
Also check L7700/01 and L8102; diode mode and voltage too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> is at 1.799V as measured at L6301
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_T</SIGNAL> is at 3.34V as measured on <CAPACITOR>C5051</CAPACITOR>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_X</SIGNAL> is at 3.38V as measured on TPC4H5

L7700 is 0.398 DM and 0.000V
L7701 is 0.091 DM and 0.000V
L8102 is 0.099 DM and 0.000V

Page 79 outputs
V3P3/<SIGNAL>VOUT_RTC</SIGNAL> = 0.135
<SIGNAL>LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> = 0.359
LDO0 = 0.213
LDO1 = 0.468
LDO2 = 0.523
LDO3 = 0.593
<SIGNAL>LDO_RTC</SIGNAL> = 0.361
<SIGNAL>HIO_SW</SIGNAL> = 0.220
VPUMP = 0.572
<SIGNAL>V3P3_SW1</SIGNAL> = 0.638
<SIGNAL>V3P3_SW2</SIGNAL> = 0.326

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message: I said page 79, not 76!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message: Sorry, on my schematic that was Page 79 of 200 (Sheet 76 of 135) so I guess you must mean Page 82 of 200 (Sheet 79 of 135). This is entitled "Power FETs"?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Okay so the diode mode readings from the Power FETs are as follows:

<CHIP>U8215</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_X</SIGNAL>) = 0.340
<CHIP>U8210</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S_T</SIGNAL>) = 0.423
<CHIP>U8220</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL>) = 0.302
<CHIP>U8240</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL>) = 0.281
<CHIP>U8297</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_TBT_X</SIGNAL>) = 0.529
<CHIP>U8295</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_TBT_T</SIGNAL>) = 0.527

Note that sense resistors <RESISTOR>R5720</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5730</RESISTOR> are both not stuffed by design as the PCB has a link between the pads.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
If you check the page number showed by Acrobat Reader in top bar, will understand the difference!

<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> may have some bad solders.
Is even possible that original/dead chip damaged some parts of T2.
Check diode mode to ground on its coils; the ones which don't get voltage at all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
I tried a reflow of <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> with plenty of flux around it and blown under it, which went pretty well and I got a successful response to the little bump with the tweezers. But exact same result when powering up again. Maybe I need to remove <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and have one more attempt at replacement to try to be sure that I've got all the connections correct. 

I agree maybe the T2 has sustained damage.

Not clear which coils you are meaning - can you clarify please and I'll check them. Thanks - I really appreciate your patience and support but I guess we're coming to the end of the road. I know there is only so much you can do when helping remotely.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Forgot to mention - I went through the power sequence for the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> from repair wiki and got quite far through it including 2.5V on <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>/1 and <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL>/1

I also found that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL> both sit at 0V but pulse at least twice to 3.34 and 1.80V respectively a short time after power up. I don't know if this gives any clues as to where it is getting to but thought I'd mention it. <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> stays at 0V as does <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> which are a bit farther down the sequence

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Hi,
I went through the power sequence as specified in the schematics and below is the result. It looks like I'm not getting <SIGNAL>PVDDQ_EN_R</SIGNAL>. This line is driven from <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>P2V5_VPP_PGOOD</SIGNAL> line) via <RESISTOR>R7756</RESISTOR>. I checked the <SIGNAL>PVDDQ_EN</SIGNAL> line which is the enable signal for <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and it is also 0V. Diode mode on <SIGNAL>PVDDQ_EN</SIGNAL> reads 0.741 and with resistance of 45.6k ohms. That matches <RESISTOR>R8153</RESISTOR> pulldown resistor and leads me to believe that maybe <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> has a bad solder joint for this line and is not able to drive it high. When I reviewed a photo I took after preparing to replace <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, this pad was not perfectly reballed but I thought it was good enough.

So I think it's worth trying to replace <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> once more and I'll make sure the balls are all perfect this time if at all possible.

Does that make sense?

Thanks.

[ATTACH type="full"]61186[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Did you get <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> from 01700 scrap board?
I had one case where was working with one from 01041.
But is not sure if accepts any replacement chip.
It has firmware and 01700 board is known to have firmware issues with <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> for example; can happen with <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Hi,
Actually the recycled <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is from an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board. I bought it as a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board after you said that the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> should work from it, but it looks like the seller sent me the wrong one and I didn't notice until I had already removed the chip. It looks quite similar to the 01700 board I'm repairing but if there is firmware on the chip then you could be right, it might be incompatible. I didn't think there was any firmware on the <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> because it's not listed in the "Programmable Parts" section in the schematics (page 3) but it makes sense that there is firmware.

I also bought a new chip from see-ic on eBay and it was described as:
[QUOTE]power Supply  IC Chip  338S00267 reball 338S00267-A0 338S00267-AO BGA IC for repair MacBook PRO A19** Logic Board 338500267 BGA IC for repair for Macbook  pro A17** repair <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  MacBook PRO A19** Logic Board Repair[/QUOTE]

Note it mentions the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> so maybe it's a better bet if I just reball it with leaded solder this time. It came with lead free solder and I didn't use enough heat when trying to fit it first time.

Let me know if you agree it's worth replacing <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> with the one I bought from see-ic or if you think I'd be better off trying to find a donor 01700 board. As you know, the 01700 board is hard to get at a good price as a donor. But iff anyone can supply a <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> chip from one to me here in the UK, ideally already reballed, then I'd be happy to buy it. Or maybe I just pay a high price for the donor board and then sell it on afterwards.

Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message: As I said, the PMU from 01041 board worked for me.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> failed, power cycling after <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR> bridged
threads.message:
Hi, I just wanted to provide a final update and to say that unfortunately I'm going to have to abandon the repair.

I reballed the chip I bought from see-ic which is supposedly compatible with the 01041 board, and this time the reball was good. However, after installing it on the board I went back to the same pulsing PPBUS which I had last time this chip was fitted and a short from L7810 to ground. At that time I postulated that maybe I had a short between the BGA solder balls but this time the soldering went really well with leaded solder so I think maybe the chip itself is faulty. That could have been caused by my original attempt at installing it where I didn't use a high enough temperature to melt the lead-free solder but probably applied the heat for too long.

As a last ditch attempt, I decided to try to reball the PMU chip I recovered from the 01814 board but the solder mask was starting to break down due to repeated repair attempts and it was just bridging all over the place. There was no way I could apply solder balls again because the balls were just flowing into what should have been masked. I hate to give up on anything but sometimes you just have to call it a day! I've got too many other demands on my time to keep going. 

I've learned a lot and I want to thank you for your help and patience. I have no doubt that the fault was with <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> which subsequently blew <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR>, but I took too many attempts to gain the skill required to complete the repair successfully.

Plan B is unfortunately to get Apple to replace the logic board and after that I'll probably sell the machine and buy a MacBook Air instead. I don't really want to continue to be the owner of a 01700 board now that I know how many issues they have!

Kind regards,
Craig.
